 * Title: guidelines-level-3: Guidelines on Own Risk Solvency Assessment .pdf:

 extract:

 **1.** **Introduction**


1.1. According to Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No. 1094/2010 of the European
Parliament and of the Council of 24 November 2010 establishing a European
Supervisory Authority (hereinafter “EIOPA Regulation”) [1,] EIOPA issues these
Guidelines addressed to the supervisory authorities on how to proceed with the
application of Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the
Council of 25 November 2009 on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of
insurance and reinsurance (hereinafter “Solvency II”) [2] .


1.2. These Guidelines are based on Articles 41, 44, 45 and Article 246 of Solvency II
and on Articles 262 and 306 of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/35
of 10 October 2014 supplementing Directive 2009/138/EC (hereinafter
“Commission Delegated Regulation 2015/35”) [3] .


1.3. Supervisory authorities are expected to ensure that undertakings take a
forward looking view on the risks to which they are exposed. 


 


        
## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

Based on the sources provided, Solvency II is the common name for **Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009** (Source 3, 4, 5).

Its full title is the directive "on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance" (Source 3). It applies to individual insurance and reinsurance undertakings (Source 4).

The directive is supplemented by other regulations, such as the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/35 (Source 1, 2, 4, 5).

The purpose of Solvency II, as indicated by the guidelines, is to establish a framework for insurance and reinsurance companies that includes:
*   **Capital Requirements**: It sets rules for calculating capital requirements, such as the Solvency Capital Requirement and specific sub-modules like the health catastrophe risk sub-module (Source 1, 2).
*   **Risk Management**: It aims to promote sound risk management within undertakings (Source 2). This includes undertakings performing their own forward-looking assessment of the risks they are exposed to (Source 5).
*   **Supervision**: The guidelines are addressed to supervisory authorities who oversee the application of Solvency II (Source 1, 2, 5).

## Question
        

 Ik heb een blootstelling naar een tegenpartij met zowel een bedrijfsobligatie als een covered bond. Hoe moet ik het SCR concentratierisico hiervoor berekenen? 


        
## Context
        

 
### source 1 

 metadata:
 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER V*

* Header 3: Section 5

* Header 4: Subsection 6

* Header 5: Article 183
:

 extract:

 **Calculation of the capital requirement for market risk concentration**


1. The capital requirement for market risk concentration shall be equal to the following:

$$
\text{{SCR}}_{{\text{{conc}}}} = \sqrt{{\sum_{{i}} \text{{Conc}}_{{i}}^{{2}}}}
$$

where:
(a)(a) the sum covers all single name exposures _i_ ;


(b) _Conc_ _i_ denotes the capital requirement for market risk concentration on a single name exposure _i_ .


2. For each single name exposure _i_, the capital requirement for market risk concentration _Conc_ _i_ shall be equal to the
loss in the basic own funds that would result from an instantaneous decrease in the value of the assets corresponding to
the single name exposure _i_ equal to the following:

$$
\text{{XS}}_{{i}} \cdot g_{{i}}
$$

where:
(a)(a) _XS_ _i_ is the excess exposure referred to in Article 184;


(b) _g_ _i_ is the risk factor for market risk concentration referred to in Articles 186 and 187;

 * Title: COMMISSION  DELEGATED  REGULATION  (EU)  2015/  35  -  of  10  October  2014  -  supplementing  Directive  2009/  138/  EC  of  the  European  Parliament  and  of  the  Council  on  the  taking-up  and  pursuit  of  the  business  of  Insurance  and  Reinsurance  (Solvency  II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

 extract:

 **Scope**


1. The capital requirement for counterparty default risk shall be equal to the following:

$$
\text{{SCR}}_{{\text{{def}}}} = \sqrt{{\text{{SCR}}^2_{{(\text{{def}},1)}} + 1,5 \cdot \text{{SCR}}_{{(\text{{def}},1)}} \cdot \text{{SCR}}_{{(\text{{def}},2)}} + \text{{SCR}}^2_{{(\text{{def}},2)}}}}
$$

where:
(a)(a) _SCR_ _def,1_ denotes the capital requirement for counterparty default risk on type 1 exposures as set out in paragraph 2;


(b) _SCR_ _def,2_ denotes the capital requirement for counterparty default risk on type 2 exposures as set out in paragraph 3.


2. Type 1 exposures shall consist of exposures in relation to the following:


(a) Risk-mitigation contracts including reinsurance arrangements, special purpose vehicles, insurance securitisations and
derivatives;


(b) Cash at bank as defined in Article 6 item F of Council Directive 91/674/EEC ( [1] );


(c) Deposits with ceding undertakings, where the number of single name exposures does not exceed 15;

1. Exposures in the form of bonds as referred to Article 52(4) of Directive 2009/65/EC (covered bonds) shall be

2. Exposures to a single immovable property shall be assigned a relative excess exposure threshold _CT_ _i_ of 10 % and a
risk factor _g_ _i_ for market risk concentration of 12 %.


3. Exposures to the following shall be assigned a risk factor _g_ _i_ for market risk concentration of 0 %:


(a) the European Central Bank;

## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

Op basis van de verstrekte bronnen moet u de blootstelling aan de bedrijfsobligatie en de covered bond behandelen als twee afzonderlijke, op zichzelf staande blootstellingen, ook al zijn ze van dezelfde tegenpartij.

Volgens artikel 187(1) worden blootstellingen in de vorm van covered bonds beschouwd als afzonderlijke "single name exposures", los van andere blootstellingen aan dezelfde tegenpartij die de covered bonds heeft uitgegeven. Deze andere blootstellingen (in dit geval de bedrijfsobligatie) vormen op hun beurt een eigen "single name exposure" (Bron 3).

De berekening van het SCR voor concentratierisico (`SCR_conc`) volgt deze stappen:

1.  **Bereken de kapitaalvereiste per blootstelling (`Conc_i`)**: Voor elke afzonderlijke blootstelling (de bedrijfsobligatie en de covered bond) berekent u de kapitaalvereiste voor concentratierisico. Deze wordt berekend als het verlies in de tier 1-basiskapitaalmiddelen als gevolg van een onmiddellijke waardedaling (Bron 1). De formule hiervoor is:
    $$ \text{{Conc}}_{{i}} = \text{{XS}}_{{i}} \cdot g_{{i}} $$
    Waarbij:
    *   `XS_i` de blootstelling boven de drempelwaarde ("excess exposure") is, zoals gedefinieerd in Artikel 184.
    *   `g_i` de risicofactor voor marktrisicoconcentratie is, zoals gedefinieerd in Artikelen 186 en 187 (Bron 1).

2.  **Specifieke behandeling voor de covered bond**: Voor de covered bond geldt een relatieve drempelwaarde voor de "excess exposure" (`CT_i`) van 15%, mits de obligatie een kredietkwaliteitsstap 0 of 1 heeft (Bron 3).

3.  **Aggregeer de individuele kapitaalvereisten**: Nadat u de `Conc_i` voor zowel de bedrijfsobligatie als de covered bond afzonderlijk heeft berekend, voegt u deze samen met de volgende formule om de totale kapitaalvereiste voor concentratierisico te bepalen (Bron 1):
    $$ \text{{SCR}}_{{\text{{conc}}}} = \sqrt{{\sum_{{i}} \text{{Conc}}_{{i}}^{{2}}}} $$
    In uw geval wordt dit:
    $$ \text{{SCR}}_{{\text{{conc}}}} = \sqrt{{\text{{Conc}}_{{\text{{bedrijfsobligatie}}}}^{{2}} + \text{{Conc}}_{{\text{{covered bond}}}}^{{2}}}} $$
